title: Toyota to Commercialize Inter-vehicle Communication System in 2015
text:
[Click to enlarge image] [Click to enlarge image] 
Toyota Motor Corp announced Sept 30, 2015, that it will commercialize an inter-vehicle communication system using the 760MHz band for the first time in the world. 
The company will release three kinds of vehicles equipped with the system within 2015. 
The inter-vehicle communication system, "ITS Connect," wirelessly exchanges data among multiple vehicles. It wirelessly receives the location information of a vehicle, pedestrian, etc in a blind spot and uses the information for safe driving. 
This time, Toyota developed two services. One is a service that improves the function of following a preceding vehicle. It controls inter-vehicle distance and vehicle speed based on the acceleration/deceleration of a preceding vehicle capable of inter-vehicle communication. Compared with the case where they are controlled based only on data collected by sensors of the user's vehicle, the new system enables to follow a preceding vehicle more smoothly. 
The other is a service that notifies the user of the existence of an emergency vehicle running near the user's vehicle. When an emergency vehicle (ambulance) capable of inter-vehicle communication sounds a siren, vehicles running near the ambulance are notified of the direction, distance and traveling direction of the ambulance. 
The inter-vehicle communication system using the 760MHz band is based on "ARIB STD-T109," a standard that was established in Japan in 2012. OFDM and CSMA/CA are used as modulation and access methods, respectively, for the standard so that it becomes similar to wireless LAN standards such as IEEE802.11a/g. The 760MHz band was assigned to ITS (intelligent transportation system) when terrestrial analog TV broadcasting ended in Japan in 2011. 
ITS Connect also enables road-to-vehicle communication. By communicating with roadside infrastructure, it notifies the user of signal waiting time, existence of a vehicle or pedestrian in a blind spot at an intersection, etc.
